Is your conclusion valid? Impulse is equal to change in momentum. The vomited milk exerts impulse on the milk man, as it is at rest relative to the milkman before being spitted out. Momentum depends on the mass and velocity. Therefore, the milk can be either super heavy, or it can be vomited at incredibly high velocity or combination of both. However your conclusion does not mention anything about the velocity of the vomited milk.
Really, anything could be broken down to make it simpler.

Actually, rocket science is pretty simple, it's just the execution that makes shit go cray. E.G. "I react hydrogen with oxygen, making an explosion, which pushes stuff away." To "I do that, but add a blast chamber (nozzle) to it to focus the explosion" to "I do that, but I had valves to the input to vary the thrust" to "I do that, but place the nozzle on a gimbalm allowing me to direct the force in the direction I want." Of course, you still need life-support and all that jazz, but still.

@schifty1 Actually it is a correct term. The basic equations of rocket propulsion are easy. To me, coming from a different part of Earth, calling something you don't understand "rocket science" is the strange thing. Quantum theory or similar would be right, but "rocket" is not really a science in my eyes, it is simply engineering, which is far from science.

@MrLarkir I was under the impression at the time that oxymorons had to be two words, one directly following the other that contradicted each other. Now that I check, I see you are right and they do not necessarily have to be consecutive.
@MrThepinkeagle No, it isn't.

Math is not the language of the universe, i.e., the universe doesn't obey the laws we defined. Rather, it's the tool we made to describe the universe. It just happens that it describes it very well, but as noted in the video, it isn't perfect. It may be that the model is wrong, like Newton's equations were wrong, but undetectably so unless you get to relativistic speeds. It may be possible that the entirety of what the universe really does can't be described with the math we invented.
